Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Strelzik with BMO Capital Markets. Please go ahead.
Andrew Strelzik -- BMO Capital Markets -- Analyst
Hey, good morning. So I know in 2018 there was an intentional reduction in the pace of innovation. I'm wondering as you reflect back on that decision, how would you assess it? And when I look at the Made to Crave menu in the innovation there that seems pretty significant relative to what happened in 2018. Is there a desire to maybe ramp that up in terms of either pace or significant to the innovation in 2019?
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yeah. If you think about 2018, we really had a focus on driving awareness around the fresh never frozen North American beef as others wanted to emulate us in our -- with our business model. So we felt good about really driving the core and really elevating the quality of our core offering. We've done something's within our restaurants to improve our operational procedures to make hotter and juicier and more melted cheese hamburgers, and we feel good about all of those.
And with that strong foundation now, we've got an opportunity to come back to our roots and be smart around innovation and do innovation that doesn't overly complex -- make the restaurant overly complex. But continue to create excitement and drive folks up. And with the lineup like Made to Crave, we've got three new hamburgers, so you've created some variety that has some staying power rather than stuff that comes and goes pretty quickly, so we feel good that that could be a platform for us into the future.
Andrew Strelzik -- BMO Capital Markets -- Analyst
Great. Thank you very much.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.
Karen Holthouse -- Goldman Sachs -- Analyst
Hi. Just a question on G&A next year and then you're tying that into the longer term view. As I just do the math on system sales growth and then G&A dollars in that guidance that we get G&A as a percentage of system sales it was like 1.8% versus the guidance we originally got at 1.5%. You've talked about some of the onetime expenses hitting the CapEx line and hitting franchise expense. Is there anything discrete within that $25 million or cost for Accenture that are also included in G&A? I'm just trying to bridge from that 1.8% to -- is 1.5% still the right longer term view?
Gunther Plosch -- Chief Financial Officer
Hey, Karen, your math is about right, so 1.8% is the number that we were sitting on with that guidance, and it's obviously a headwind for us as compared to 2018. So what are the puts and takes in there. The puts and take is we almost had to refund the incentive comp of about $5 million. We have a reinvestment in the G&A line year-over-year of about $5 million. It's between international and digital and it's permanent it's here to stay to make sure we can grow the way we want to grow.
And then obviously that sort of $10 million of headwind and we are offsetting that with about $5 million carryover incremental savings out of the final leg of our G&A restructuring initiative that we had filed previously.
So as I said earlier, a little bit behind as a percent of sales metrics, which we originally thought. It's definitely a function of that our system sales have grown a little bit less than what we have anticipated, seems to be a bullish on our outlook. What don't want to do is, we don't want to cut out G&A and then hurt us for a long-term growth prospect. So we know our target is 1.5%. We might get there a little bit later.
Karen Holthouse -- Goldman Sachs -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Peter Saleh will BTIG. Please go ahead.
Peter Saleh -- BTIG -- Analyst
Great. Thank you. I just want to come back to the conversation around delivery and digital. On the delivery side, are you guys seeing in the data repeat visits from customers? Or is what you're seeing predominantly trial of delivery for the first time?
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
It's been good. We create awareness clearly see the trial. The good news is for the folks that are trying and are aware, we're seeing a nice repeat and we've got a great partnership with our delivery partners to create awareness. Some of the things they're funding to create awareness and create compelling economic model for delivery. We're creating some awareness with some of the advertising support that we have and some of those providers are even advertising their own brands now.
Our opportunity is really as I said earlier, how do we even drive more awareness, so more folks know they can get delivery from Wendy's. And as we build out from 60% of our system being able to support delivery at the end of 2018 to 80% during 2019, we can continue to advertise whether it's nationally or locally and create that awareness and our partners will do the same.
Peter Saleh -- BTIG -- Analyst
So would you be increasing your -- the funds associated with delivery in terms of advertising this year or allocating more funds toward advertising that capability?
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes. I think we'll continue to do what we've done during 2018 efficiently use some of our funds. And what you've seen in a lot around key events when consumers are home, we make sure that they know that they can have their food delivered to them. We've been smart around taking some things and we've been smart in our partnerships with our delivery partners. During key events when folks are at home, where they actually fund some of the delivery expense to make sure we can create some excitement for people to try and when they have a great experience they try to repeat.
Gunther Plosch -- Chief Financial Officer
And it's also nice to see that DoorDash themselves started to advertise to create -- to increase their own brand awareness and we're really happy that our brand is featuring actually in their advertisement as well.
Peter Saleh -- BTIG -- Analyst
Great. And then just lastly I think you guys were testing kiosks and some stores. Where do you stand on the kiosk implementation? Are you planning to roll this out in 2019 to more franchisees? Are they interested in adopting this?
Gunther Plosch -- Chief Financial Officer
Hi. Yes. Kiosk is as we always said going slower than planned. I think it's an important part in our -- surrounding our consumers digitally, but it's slower than we thought, right? So we have it in 60% of our restaurants. We're really trying to put money where our mouth is, so we're trying to prove the business case, the business case is there. You get slightly higher check sizes to get revenue growth. You get throughput enhancement in busy, busy day part and in the slower day part, you get a chance to take labor out. So it pays out. It's up to us as a franchisor to prove our total investments to hopefully then accelerate the excitement within the franchise community.
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes, so that's 60%, it's 60% in the company restaurants. Just to have that clear. So again, we're leading the system to really prove the benefits and a lot of it comes down to labor positioning, how do we educate the consumer and it may not be right for all trade areas and that's part of the learning that we have, but we do feel it's a compliment to the whole digital strategy. There's a role in place for kiosk as well as mobile ordering and all of the other things that we are doing.
Peter Saleh -- BTIG -- Analyst
Great. Thank you very much.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Dennis Geiger with UBS. Please go ahead.
Dennis Geiger -- UBS -- Analyst
Great. Thanks. Wonder if you could give any comments on unit development agreements currently. What the multiyear pipeline looks like. I think in the past you've kind of either given number of commitments or the percent of commitments that are locked in. And then just separately, just wondering if there's any update you could give on the First Kitchen conversions in Japan where that stands? And if there's any way to think about the cadence going forward? Thanks.
Gunther Plosch -- Chief Financial Officer
Hi, Dennis. On the development agreement, we've made great progress toward the ground-break incentive that really is exciting news for our franchisees and it definitely led to incremental development agreement over and above agreement had been committed previously. On a global basis, about 50% plus is committed and secured via development agreements.
On the First Kitchen side, we are making good progress with our progression. I think we have about a little bit north of a-third of the First Kitchen restaurants converted in Japan. Obviously, with plans to do further of them in 2019.
Dennis Geiger -- UBS -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Your next question will come from the line of Jon Tower with Wells Fargo. Please go ahead.
Jon Tower -- Wells Fargo -- Analyst
Awesome. Great. Thanks. You've answered quite a few question. So I just want to hit on a couple. First, on your mobile acquisition strategy, can you put some numbers around perhaps app downloads and registered users?
The next on Image Activations. How should we think about the pacing over the next couple of years. I know you targeted 70% by 2020. Is that still on track? And then that franchise flips going forward. I know you talked about historically doing roughly 200 a year, this year it was about 100-store shortfall. How should we think about that over the next couple of years? Thank you.
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes. So we do internally really track where our active users are. It's a metric that we're not going to provide externally. Our job is really about driving the acquisition and keeping them in. So it's really about active users. Get them in, get them to stay in there and get them to continue to use our app and we'll look at it based on external third-party competitive benchmarking to really understand where we stand.
On Image Activation, since we are ahead of pace as we ended 2018, we will see a continued growth in it. We'll probably end up, I would guess, in that 65% to 70%, so we're still feeling bullish and optimistic that we'll get close to 70% reimaged by the time we get to 2020.
Good investment, good return and good opportunity to continue to bring in more customers more often. And on franchise flips, we'll probably see in a ballpark of 100 to 200 franchise flips during the course of 2019. You also got to remember there is other activity that goes on with franchise to franchise transactions that we get actively involved in.
So one of it is what interest is there from our franchise community to get our help and then where do we have to help and get involved in other activity, because we only have so many folks that can work on these deals and that was some of the balance that you would have sown last year, right.
We had 96 franchise flips but we had about 320 restaurants change hands during the course of the year and our teams actively involved in all of that to ensure that we're building a stronger system for the future.
Jon Tower -- Wells Fargo -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Your final question will come from the line of Bob Derrington with Telsey Advisory Group. Please go ahead.
Robert Derrington -- Telsey Advisory Group -- Analyst
Yes. Thank you. G.P., typically you've given us some color about the contribution from the Image Activation program to same-store sales. For this last year system -- North America system sales -- same-store sales were up 0.9%. How much of that would you attribute to the Image Activation program? And I've got a follow-up.
Gunther Plosch -- Chief Financial Officer
Hey, Bob. The tailwind from Image Activation was about 50 basis points.
Robert Derrington -- Telsey Advisory Group -- Analyst
50 basis points. Okay, terrific. And Todd, one thing that I'm wondering as a look at typically ordering Wendy's through DoorDash here in the local market. Typically the retail prices are marked up approximately 30% to 35%. What kind of feedback do you get from any -- either your stores or your customers about that higher price versus the retail store price?
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes, from a restaurant level, we don't get any feedback, right, because they're not taking a big impact and big hit to restaurant margin, so they feel good. This is a truly incremental business and incremental profit for them and that's why they get very excited to get behind it and support it.
From a consumer perspective, which we'll have to continue to watch and look at the consumer economic model, we haven't seen any adverse impacts, right? If you think about our ratings in DoorDash, we're consistently 4.5, 4.6 out of 5 on their rating scales.
The overall satisfaction and we track overall satisfaction both in the restaurant, drive-thru, takeaway, and delivery. Our highest overall satisfaction is still on a delivered order, so we're getting there -- we're getting the food to the consumer fast and hot and they feel good about that overall experience.
So, we're feeling good that we've got the right balance over the long-term to make sure that it's healthy for us and that the consumer is still highly satisfied, and we'll continue to watch it.
Robert Derrington -- Telsey Advisory Group -- Analyst
So, you think that generally consumers are beginning to understand that there is no such thing as free delivery and paying a higher retail price versus in-store, it's just part of the service they get.
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes, I think exactly right Bob. At the end of the day, convenience continues to be redefined, right? We continue to drive a lot of convenience with our traditional drive-thru. Convenience now is how do you get food hot and fast to your house and folks know that that's not for free and it is going to cost a little bit because that last mile does take some economic pressure to get there, but they really price having the food that they want delivered to them when they want it. And as I said earlier Food at Home is our biggest competitor. So, if you we can provide more access that way, that's a good thing for the brand.
Robert Derrington -- Telsey Advisory Group -- Analyst
Terrific. Thanks Todd.
Todd A. Penegor -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Thanks.
Greg Lemenchick -- Director, Investor Relations
Thank you, Bob. That was our last question of the call. Thank you, Todd and G.P. and thank everyone for participating this morning. We look forward to speaking with you again next quarter when we report on our first quarter results. Have a great day. You may now disconnect.
